Award.AbstractNarration:
CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: CyberMech, a novel run-time substrate for cyber-mechanical systems

Growing demands on our civil infrastructure have heightened the need for smart structural components and systems whose behavior and performance can be controlled under a variety of loading scenarios such as high winds and earthquakes. However, due to the sheer size, scale and cost of most civil engineering structures, design and testing of such smart structures needs to be conducted using a hybrid cyber-physical approach where the infrastructure system in question, for example a bridge, is studied by coupling a small number of physical components with a numerical model of the rest of the structure. Undoubtedly, the success of such a hybrid approach, especially for dynamic real-time applications, hinges on effective integration of the cyber and physical components of the system. This project provides the essential building blocks and a computational integration platform to enable real-time hybrid testing of civil engineering structures.

Design and development of physical components, multi-level numerical models, and real-time control algorithms will be conducted at Purdue University. Washington University will provide an adaptive, configurable concurrency platform and communication mechanisms that meet the strict scheduling constraints of real-time cyber-physical systems. The two institutions will collaboratively design a prototype system and conduct extensive testing to validate the integration of the various components and evaluate system performance. Specifications, software, benchmarks, and data developed during the course of this project will be made freely available to the cyber-physical research community. In addition to directly advancing the state-of-the-art in real-time hybrid testing, this research will also impact the areas of avionics, automotive design, smart grids for distributed power transmission and similar applications in other domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Real-time hybrid simulation (RTHS) is a cyber-physical testing technique used to examine the global behavior of structural systems that are too large or complex to test in the laboratory (e.g. buildings, bridges). Physical specimens are linked with computational models, and the challenge is to ensure that the combined system is tested under realistic conditions. Thus, boundary conditions at the interface between the physical and computational portions must be enforced at a sufficiently high frequency (usually about 1000 times a second), and mechanical devices such as shake tables and hydraulic actuators are frequently used. However, the relatively slow dynamics of these devices and the presence of feedback loops, mean that delays and lags hinder realistic simulations, and thus control is needed. Because the system being examined is not well understood (which is the point of the test), control design must be performed under large uncertainty. Thus, RTHS is highly interdisciplinary, requiring deep expertise in mechanics, control, signal processing, and computer engineering.

This project focused on creative and rigorous approaches to tackling challenges associated with RTHS. In partnership with researchers in Computer Science and Engineering at Washington University, we developed a software, called CyberMech, that provides  a state-of-the-art parallel real-time computational platform for RTHS and similar other applications. For the first time, it enables the use of parallel multi-core computing in RTHS which has significantly improved the quality of these simulations.

In addition, we also developed a suite of methods to design effective and accurate RTHS experiments. Our analytical method will help to quantify how choices made in partitioning of a complete structure, into physical and computational portions, play a major role in the success of an RTHS experiment. We developed a quantitative measure of this ability: the predictive stability indicator (PSI) and a complementary method for predicting the accuracy of an RTHS, the predictive performance indicator (PPI). Prior RTHS studies did not question or quantify the accuracy of the test, nor did they consider the barriers in enforcing boundary conditions. However, with the indicators developed here, researchers are able to use these tools to design a successful RTHS experiment in advance.

In our final showcase experiment, we integrated the capabilities developed within this project to conduct a series of experiments that highlights the strengths of our CyberMech platform. Using a scaled model of a building, and a highly nonlinear and rate dependent structural damping device (see Figure), RTHS experiments were conducted. A large computational model was developed to represent the structure. The main conclusions from this experiment were:

  • When a single processor is used for the computations, CyberMech is able to increase the sampling rate possible by a factor of ~5 compared to traditional methods, thus enabling the testing of systems with higher contributing frequencies.
  • When several processors are used, CyberMech is able to execute the same amount of work notably much faster, or, to execute models that are significantly larger than existing standard platforms. For example, CyberMech running with 23 cores is able to increase the sampling rate by a factor of 32.
  • Overall, CyberMech enables RTHS tests with much larger models than ever before possible.

Impact of the Research: The methods developed herein, and resulting codes, are key enablers for both the verification of novel structural systems that resist extreme dynamic loads, such as earthquakes, hurricanes, tsunamis and tornados. This research is already transforming the ways in which we evaluate structural behavior.

Dissemination: The project has been presented at a number of conferences, and is enabling the development of a benchmark problem on tracking control for RTHS. Researchers from around the world are being invited to participate and apply their techniques to this challenging problem to build capacity in RTHS. A series of tests was performed with different configurations, including (virtual) vRTHS and RTHS tests, as well as pure numerical simulations.
